reviewText:
LOTS OF TEXT, SERIOUS REVIEW -- NO '10/10' JOKES HERE

Let me begin with this review that it being very cheap (only $7!) feels like I'm pirating the game, when you compare the quality to the price. I would pay $20 for this game and still get the same out of it, though if you want to pick up copies for friends (trust me when I say you'll want to after you get a taste) or if you're simply a cheapskate, and the below text appeals to you, you would be making a mistake not to buy this game.


This is easily the best game purchase I've ever made, and I don't regret buying it for around four other people within my first few hours of playing.

Like games such as Dungeon Crawl Stone Soup, Dwarf Fortress, and other roguelikes, though especially NetHack (which is renowned as the grandfather of every roguelike and video game RPG that exist), this game will eat you, chew you, spit you out, set you on fire, and then stomp on you; and that's on a good day, and usually only if you're playing with friends.
But like games such as Quake, DOOM, and other classic first person shooters, the controls are easy enough to get used to, while not compromising complexity or challenge.

Roguelikes tend to be represented by tileset based graphics like a board game, or letters/numbers/other characters to represent things in the game world. They're also turn based, and typically never multiplayer due to the turn based gameplay.

Barony violates these 'rules of the roguelike' with the following:

- can be played with up to 4 people (extremely important)
- a three-dimensional voxel graphic system (3D pixel-ish, but is still very aesthetically pleasing, and actually feels nostalgic with a 90s feel unlike your average game that uses pixel art graphics for no good reason)
- a first person perspective (as opposed to a board game look where you see everything from above)
- real time gameplay (roguelikes are usually always turn based)

There are probably other important roguelike rules I'm missing, yet, despite these changes, this game is the purest example (besides NetHack itself) of what a roguelike is, and is largely directly inspired by NetHack (not the same story, but definitely the same spiritually). These are not criticisms. The fact that Barony can manage these changes while still feeling like a true roguelike every step of the way is what proves it to be as good as I'm making it out to be. (in fact, these changes make the game easier for people to pick up and get into, but that's just my opinion)


In terms of what a classic dungeon crawling roguelike should have, Barony excels in such:

- death is permanent
- extremely hard and unforgiving
- extremely fun overall (in terms of actual fun, and Dwarf Fortress 'Losing is Fun!' fun)
- cryptic and doesn't make anything obvious (while every bottle of swirly orange liquid will do the same thing, it won't tell you what it does unless the effect itself is obvious, like invisibility -- only if you identified it through appraisal or a scroll of identify will it tell you what it does before you drink it)
- many levels, with randomized layouts that change every time
- is NOT simple, even though it looks like it is (you normally wouldn't expect eating too much to be a problem, until your character vomits and suddenly you're starving to death because your stomach is empty)
- lets you learn from your dying experiences so you know not to make the same mistakes -- this is very important, as death is a learning experience as opposed to you simply not being good enough or bad luck
- also is likely to make your death hilarious as opposed to frustrating
- near death experiences are also very fun (don't believe me? you will after you escape a minotaur)
- many different ways to play
- many secrets
- a lot more that i'm forgetting

In addition, Barony's co-op play is not only extremely fun, but somehow turns the death of every party member except you from horribly frustrating to uncontrollable laughter at the circumstances through which your friends died. It somewhat violates the permadeath rule in that the party heading to the next level respawns who died, but this is offset by the fact that you may not be able to carry all of the equipment that your friends had to return it, and that your chance of surviving long enough to get to the next level to revive them is as low as their chance not to die first was.

My only complaint is that even though I haven't beaten it as of the time of writing this review, and probably won't for a very long time, there doesn't seem to be that much content in comparison to NetHack as far as levels go (from my understanding of the game's insides, the shortest a game can be is 20 levels), and there could be more tiers of equipment beyond wooden/bronze/iron/steel (correct me if i'm wrong).

Condensed, here's what I think of the various aspects:

Graphics - 8/10 (this is probably because i'm biased toward old school voxel graphics, but if Minecraft is pleasing to your eye, Barony will be something your eyes will savor)
Sound - 7/10 (could be more realistic, but the sound effects do easily match the graphics, which are old school)
Music - 9/10 (very fitting, and very nostalgic)
Gameplay - 10/10 (see everything I wrote above)

As far as suggestions go, if the developers or anyone influential on the game's direction can read this, I would suggest more equipment, more enemies and maybe more bosses (skeletons are cool and all, but i'd love to see more), more levels, pretty much more everything if there's no plans to already. NetHack had an absolutely overwhelming number of enemies, items such as wands, weapons, potions (which were randomly generated in every playthrough! I would recommend having a system such as that, akin to Binding of Isaac's randomly generated pill effects), etc. Of all those, my main request would be more enemies. As a nice addition, perhaps sliders or difficulty/'complication' levels would be a good idea to either new or hardcore players, as too much can easily overwhelm a person (which NetHack does with no problem) and spoil their experience -- though balanced in such a way that it still remains true to it's roguelike roots.
All of this said however, the developers are already doing an amazing job, and the above are simple suggestions that I think, from my experiences of playing NetHack and other roguelikes, would greatly enhance the game. This may not reflect the vision of the developers.

Final Judgement - 10/10
If you like everything I wrote above, are tired of more casual games being too easy, want some more challenge, love NetHack and want something similar, love NetHack and want to play it with friends, or are just looking for the next RPG to sink your time into, get this game.

Or get this game anyway and see how many times you die in your first two hours. (My count: 43)

(also add me on Steam if you want someone to play this with!)

Do I recommend this game? Emphatically.

First there will be a general overview of the game, followed by a breakdown of its parts.

Barony is a game that honestly surprised me. I didn't actually want to get it at first, but was convinced by a friend. Don't let the graphics or negative reviews by people who have played for 10 minutes turn you off. This is a genuinely satisfying game with challenging but fair gameplay and simple RPG elements, such as unique equipment, rare encounters, and stats and skills that grow as you use them. Despite its simplistic nature, the game has surprising depth and replayability. A variety of classes all with unique starting equipment and playstyles, random dungeons and loot, so many ways to live or die, and secrets to top it all off, it is well worth the $7 you pay.

While there are some people who can't handle permadeath, the game plays in such a way that failure feels like an experience instead of a loss. If you have a good mindset and learn from your mistakes instead of blaming something else. It makes you want to play again to overcome a failure that was ultimately your own. You need to be careful to survive. Peek around every corner, and keep an eye out for traps. My best character, who'd found the legendary spear Gungnir, become an expert at magic, felled the minotaur, and was strong enough to move boulders, died to a spike trap that I was entirely aware of, I just turned too soon when passing it. If I'd been more careful, I might have beaten the game, as I was very well equipped at that point. The moral of the story is that you are never untouchable. This game doesn't cater to your power fantasies the way games like Skyrim do. You can't faceroll through it without ever dying. You are quite mortal, regardless of how lucky you get with gear. And I like that about the game. It's never *too* easy.

For some, this first part may be enough. But for people on the fence, we'll take a more in-depth look at the game and its features.

Both me and a friend have had issues with resolution. reviewText:
For the first time, I don't feel let down by the promise of a first person Roguelike.

I've only played a few games, but this game is deeper than your usual roguelike-like and its difficulty is uncompromising. Don't expect any hand-holding while you delve into the dungeons of this game.

While this isn't on par with the wide variety of actions in a traditional roguelike, Barony already offers most of what you would want, from cursed objects, unidentified items, spells and wide variety of equipment. The first person adds some interesting ideas, making booze interesting and displaying some effects in a rather amusing maner... just wait until you get some poisoned or rotten food and you'll see what I mean.

One of the most questionable aspects of the game is the mouse driven inventory management. I do find that to be kind of a mess and would prefer to have the option to use my keyboard instead.
A lot of the fights will also require you to be reactive. Since everything happens in real time, you won't have time to think and ponder your equipment choices for too long.

I have yet to try the multi-player portion of the game and will probably update my review accordingly.

As it stands I do consider this game to be the best first person roguelike experience I've ever had, right in front of Delver.

reviewText:
Okay, so first and foremost I am going to say that I do enjoy this game thoroughly.  However, this is a review and I have many good things and some bad things to say about this game.  Beginning with the good.

Good Stuff
Barony is a genuinely challenging and fun game to play.  This game has a ton of items with all kinds of attributes, melee weapons, staffs, bows, crossbows, levitation, water walking, and much more great stuff.  Also, this game comes with what I think is one of the coolest identifying systems I have ever seen in their appraisal technique.  Furthermore, this game comes packed with some sweet spells for you to use.  I even really love the steep learning curve on this game.  BUT, with all that good stuff being said, I think the developers could make it one of the best games of it's kind if they fixed a few things that I will outline here.

Bad Stuff
Barony RARELY lets you actually use some of the best spells in the game, and on top of that some of the character types will never be able to use certain spells at all throughout the game.  I understand barbarians and warriors probably aren't known for using spells.  BUT, you need spells and/or ranged weapons in order to fight the last boss.  He literally can not be fought melee.  So, either you use a low damage bow, or crossbow.... Ohh, wait forget everything I just said, forget the spells, melee, ranged, all you really need is one of the super overpowered staffs which can be used by any class and literally obliterate any enemy in the game.  On top of that, these staffs run out of charge but if you leave it alone for a bit, it just RECHARGES and you can begin the pwnage once more.  These are also the best weapons to use on the last boss (the only weapon I know of that I can even kill the last boss with).    This makes using any of the other weapons pretty much obsolete in terms of most of the classes.  Also, there is a large difficulty gap at the beginning - and then - the game flat out gets easy.  I think the main problem lies in the item system.  You can actually get the best items/weapons in the game right in the first level if you are lucky.  Sure, there are gimmicks like the boulders, traps, etc to kill you, but otherwise you pretty much don't have to worry about any enemies once you get a staff and some decent armor.  I think the HARDEST part of this game is actually keeping your character well fed.  Food is scarce, to say the least, most of the time you are praying for a scroll of food to keep from dying.  This isn't a bad thing, I just don't think it should be your literal number one concern in a game like this.

reviewText:
One of the few games where you can survive on cream pies, huddled in the corner of  a dungeon.

Barony is a roguelike (or roguelite, if you prefer) that's take a lot of inspiration from Ultima Underworld, and that's a very, very good thing. The player is thrown into a dungeon that is sectioned off into different areas, battling things from skeletons and rats to demons and succubi. While classes are offered at the beginning, they realistically only determine your style of play for the first few floors. Skills are not bound by class, and a wizard is just as able to train in swords and axes as a barbarian is able to train in spellcraft and item appraisal.

The dungeon is randomly generated in chunks, with equally random loot scattered throughout it. Danger lurks around every bend in the form of boulder traps, cursed amulets of strangulation and skull-thumping tolls, and if those don't kill you, your hunger will. Barony is brutal, but not insurmountable, and those odds can be evened out with a few friends; cooperative play is featured for four players over internet or LAN, allowing for pals to die together in the depths of Baron Herx's dungeon.

There's a few bugs, and there could be a few things better balanced, but what's here currently is very playable and very enjoyable for anyone looking for a first person dungeon crawler with freeform character improvement and various perils to overcome. A level editor is also included, so once you've become a master of Baron Herx's dungeon you're free to create your own.

reviewText:
[Edited to include Cursed Edition additions.]

Pros/Cons
Pros:
+Randomized Dungeons
+Hardcore Roguelike Elements
+First-Person Perspective
+Jolly Co-operation!
+(New!) Adjust 'Flags' that you want in your game, including: Minotaur, Hunger(!), Friendly Fire, etc.

Maybes:
=Perma-death. I like it. Some won't.
=Voxel Graphics
=(New!) There's apparently a 60fps cap now?

Cons:
-Hunger is ludicrous. You will be starved every 3 minutes or so, and be lucky to find more than one to three sources of [filling] foods on a floor. Randomized dungeons are great in that you get to explore a different map each time, but hunger destroys that feeling as it forces you to bum-rush many floors.

-Development team will take offense to anyone's suggestions and ban them.

-Blocking only with shields. You cannot do a one-handed sword/axe/mace block/parry.

-Some things just don't make sense. I can break doors/chairs/tables/chests, but I can't break the small, wooden torches on the wall. I can one-handedly shoot a bow while holding a shield. Weapons degrade, but armor doesn't. Etc.

-I have to grab (since I can't break) insane amounts of torches just to stay hidden in the dark, thus slowing me down unless I spend 3 minutes dropping them one by one...which then I'll be hungry and probably die of starvation.

-Game is incredibly short. It will only take you around half an hour to reach the boss if you're taking it slow. 10 minutes if you rush. There's only 25 levels from what I've seen.

-Very limited beginning customization. This is the first roguelike I've played that didn't let me invest/randomize my own stats and/or create at least some minor form of backstory.

-Dungeons aren't as random as they advertise it to be. You will see near-exactly the same maps over and over again, with exact same methods of exit.

-The Baron Herx boss fight is 100% artificial difficulty. Instead of making him boss-worthy, they just put a ton of health on him and only two moves.

My Story:On ocassion, I would go on a rant with my buds in the Dark Souls chatroom about the glory days of playing Diablo II. I complained because I was depressed. Year after year, games began to lose replay value, co-op became a Hollywood stunt rather than a pact of survivalism, and the era of fear in dungeon-based gaming closed further to null.

This game isn't a Hollywood stunt, so there's that.

5.5/10 -- The potential is there, but has yet to be halfway met. Buy it when it's under $5. Otherwise, you're going to be incredibly disappointed.

reviewText: This game was gifted to me before it became available on Steam, so the playtime counter is not an accurate representation of how many hours of my life I've devoted to Barony. Completely unforgiving in its difficulty, a fair degree of how much success you'll have during a run is at the whim of the Random Number God; what loot you find, whether or not that floor has a shopkeeper, and how much precious, precious food you can acquire.\nIf you enjoy roguelike dungeon crawling and can cope with the frustration of having to start over from the very beginning after death you may well find your hard-earned income well spent on this title. And if your friends are into that sort of thing too, bonus: multiplayer is supported!\nA final cautionary note: although the dev is working to develop one, there is at the time of this review no save feature, so if you hope to play the game through to a successful conclusion you will need to have an hour or two to devote to the task.

reviewText:
Let me tell you a story about some unlucky adventurers;

It began, as you might expect, in the land of wherever-this-is-land; Lord Flix, mighty warrior and dashing gentleman, with a thirst for glory and adventure ventured unto yon dungeon.

“Well, alright, I’ve got a table, wonder if I can bash with my spear” Whack whack whack, “yes I can can. Ah! that’ll learn you stupid table”. He walked right to the gate, pulled the lever and climbed down the ladder. “Well then, this is a fine dungeon indeed ! A bit dark mind, but overall fine looking. Uh what’s this then ?” Lord Flix picked up a queer looking stone off the ground and looked deeply into it, like way more than a sane person would. I mean it’s just a rock. “Hum, a rock. Wonder if I can throw it” fwooooop thunk. “Why yes I can”. But Flix’s untimely and rash rock throwing catched the gaze of a vile skeleton. They both looked into each other’s eyes, bloodlust was in the air. He knew that this ungodly abomination would have ill intent towards him. They would have to fight. “Roight, have at thee vile undead !” whack whack whack “Wait, how do I use my shield ? Gaaarrffffh” Alas ! If only Lord Flix knew how to parry the many swords strike that fell on him he might live today. But it was not so….

Thus begat the adventure of Lord Flix II.

“Right ! Better do some shield trainning then, I don’t wanna die again” and he did, a lot, a lot. With renewed inspiration and courage he went down the ladder just like his predecessor. “Hum a rat, I guess I can take on a rat” whack whack “WOOO I killed my first thing ! I am mighty indeed !” For a long time Lord Flix II simply wandered aimlessly, never encountering another soul. But his resolve was put to the test; he could not see any monsters, but he could hear them. The queer, unnerving sound that only a vile beast of the underworld could make. “Screw me ! Where you at monsters ? Came at me bra!” Still no sign of life, yet the eldritch sound was there, always there. “Uh what’s this then ? A hole in the celling ? Why that looks interes…” BLAAM. A giant boulder fell of the hole and squashed mighty Lord Flix II to death.

Thus begat the adventure of Lord Flix III

“Mmmkay, in retrospect that was fairly predictable”. For Lord Flix III knew of the dire end of both his predecessors, somehow, because of magic maybe ? Yeah let’s go with magic. Anyhoo you know the drill, down the ladder we go ! “ He wandered thither and hither, slayed a bunch of rats and skeleton along the way. He felt mighty, powerful, and emboldened by the knowledge he gathered from they who dwelt here afore him. “Well would you look at that, a fountain ! Why that’s not suspicious in any way, nooooooope” With that in mind our handsome hero drank deep from the fountain, assured that he would receive some boom for a kindly spirit or something. Alas ! It was not so, to nobody’s surprise. We never said that the Flix bloodline was particuarly smart y’know. He felt quite dizzy from the water, perhaps some foul wizard had cast a vile spell on it ? Suddenly he realized he wasn’t alone, sharing the room with him was a naked blue lady. Because that’s not weird or anything. “You wot ? Where’d you came from ? Why are you laughing ? Hold on there keep your distance I don’t thrust you” Slaaaaaaap ! “Did you just slapped me ? Oh hell no, Imma thrust my spear right into your face you dumb blue lady !” he paused for a second and thought about what he said “Wait, that came out wrong, meh, scew it” But Lord Flix III did not know that this blue lady was in fact a dreaded Succubus, the vile seductress from beyond the veil of reality ! A mighty opponent indeed ! Anyway you probably know where this is going.

Thus begat the adventure of Lord Flix IV

And down the ladder we go ! But this time to our fiercely awesome hero’s surprise the first door was locked ! “Whatever shall I do ! “ He tried and tried and tried to open it to no success. “Wait, damnit I’m such an idiot ! I can just bash the damn thing”. And he did, and he also felt really dumb, ‘cause you know, the solution was obvious. Anyway after a bit of exploring he ended up in a dark maze-like part of the dungeon. He didn’t want to sacrifice his shield for a torch even though he had collected like, an ungodly amount of the damned thing. He slowed down wary and looking everywhere for any sign of ambush. He might have been carefull but two skeletons did ambushed him anyway. “GAAARRGGDFDFJH  ARE YOU KIDDING ME YOU SUNAVA….” whack whack.

Thus Ended the life of Lord Flix IV, and also this “review”

That’s a good game, that ! Well if you like 3D maze-like dungeon, and rogue-like elements, and permadeath. Also for the love of god, stock up on light sources, mind the celling and watch out for blue ladies in fountains.

reviewText:
Barony is one of the closest roguelites I've played to a proper roguelike but it is marred by a few issues which I will focus on (because all the good stuff is covered exaustively by reviews other than mine).

Firstly, the single save slot is frustrating when trying to play multiplayer with friends who don't have the time to sit down for a single run. It requires you to delete your save to start another game. I haven't confirmed wether or not manually managing your save files gets around this (I assume it does) but it's annoying that I have to go out of the game just to play single player between my multiplayer games.

Secondly, some of the items aren't very random. Potions and staves have sprites that pretty much tell you what they do, it's very easy to metagame and in my opinion anathema to classic roguelike gameplay. I haven't been paying enough attention to say if the same applies to scrolls but my assumption is it doesn't.

The fact that you cannot rebind the attack and interact buttons is the most inexplicable and infuriating gripe I have. I can only assume that it is blatant incompetence that resulted in these being hardcoded, because there is no reason they should not be rebindable like the rest of the controls.

Overall I'm giving this a negative review because the steam rating doesn't reflect what I think the game deserves, not because I don't recommend the game. As others have pointed out, it's a great coop roguelike.

Edit: I consider the price hike unjustified. The amount of actual content added is minimal; the changes are primarily visual. Additionally I think there is too little variation between the new faces that replaced the old ones, although they are higher definition, they do not give the same distinct and exclusive impressions the old ones had.

Second Edit: The price hike never seems to have happened. Interesting...

Straight forward roguelike with nothing interesting or new to experience. I didn't have any fun with this one mostly due to a shallow and tedious combat system (mash the attack button while trading blows since walking backwards is made too slow to allow for dodging), extremely dark levels that require a torch at all times which renders shields useless, and finally instant unpredictable deaths that ruin the exploration. Combat in itself is cheap as you must trade blows, your equipment and stats are the only thing that determines success which is very traditional of very old school RPGs but has never felt right to me. It's a shame though because there's a lot of cool assets here and the overall ascetic is nice even if generic. The shallow ceilings are a bit of an eyesore but the voxel graphics are neat. Overall a solid roguelike held back by archaic game design and lack of originality.

Recommended only for roguelike fanatics.

reviewText:
I decided to spend the remainder of my Steam Wallet on this game. It seemed interesting, with enough of a challenge to keep me entertained. However, I was very disappointed with my purchase. Here are some problems with Barony:

The UI needs work. Even though Hunger is an effect, there is no meter to show how hungry you are. Only an icon that pops up on occasion. You become hungry at the worst possible times. And when you try to sell an item, it isn't straightforward. Half the fun of loot is selling it, and you can't. When items are damaged, you can't tell. There is no durability meter on items. They seem to break at random.

The game is lacking even a simplistic tutorial. It's irritating to have to figure out controls from online guides and the Settings menu.

Why is there a guy selling things in the dungeon? It makes no sense.

Combat sucks. Enemy swings can barely be seen, so you can't time enemy strikes. And shields don't provide as much protection as they should. Shields in Minecraft, for example, were implemented very well, providing players a great deal of protection from enemy strikes. But the shields in Barony feel like they're full of holes. With weapons, swings feel sloppy; like I have little control of how far my swing goes. I have the modify the FOV heavily to find the right distance. In Daggerfall, the FOV was fine, since the weapon is seen swinging at a distance, rather than the hacking motion from Minecraft. The FOV isn't a problem in Minecraft, because enemies aren't swinging weapons at you. They just cause damage or shoot projectiles. Combat feels chaotic and sloppy; this could be remedied with faster movement, allowing for fast-paced dodging. This is how it worked in Daggerfall. Also, Daggerfall used a random damage system. Players could only determine if they are close enough to strike with their weapon. Blocks and damage were generated at random. This worked well. However, your character feels slow, and enemy strikes can rarely be avoided. In a game as difficult as Barony, a strong melee system is very much needed.

The system of appraising items sucks. Only the Merchant can reliably appraise items. It makes sense if the other classes appraise slowly. But if you have to wait an entire minute to appraise an item, only for the appraisal to fail, it wastes time, puts characters in danger, and takes the fun out of looting (My favorite part of RPGs, btw). Appraise skill should simply increase the speed of appraisals instead of increase reliability. It hurts people early in the game. Also, more items should be general items, without need for appraisal. In Diablo, for example, most loot weapons don't need to be identified. However, the only items that do need identification are magic items. This made identification VERY satisfying, since it was always a pleasant surprise to see what powers a magic weapon had. But in Barony, players are often left disappointed with their new items once they are appraised. Also, you should not need to appraise food. That's ridiculous. Food just needs a sniff and a once over, not an appraisal of value.

It makes sense that the game is a difficult roguelike, and that all loot and level progress is lost upon death. However, you should be able to save characters, so experience isn't lost. The fact that you lose absolutely ALL progress if you die is extremely frustrating. The game stops being enjoyably hard and start being frustrating when you gain XP, only to die easily later on. At least in DARK SOULS, you keep your level when you die.

Mana and Health recharge VERY slowly. This was okay in Daggerfall, since the designers were fresh D&D players who didn't know better. When Daggerfall was made, it was based on D&D combat. D&D combat lasted far longer per enemy, so high mana and health costs were okay. But in a Videogame, you need that health and mana back very quickly. In Daggerfall, the player could rest in order to regain lost health. However, you have no way other than random potions to rapidly regain health in Barony. And note that those potions might be poisonous. Therefore, it is VERY easy to die. Or you have to wait several minutes to regain health and mana. This slows the game's pace immensely.

Items become cursed very easily, for no apparent reason. Loot becomes unusable. I cannot stress enough how much I LOOOOVE Looting in RPGs. So when all the loot I find becomes useless for no good reason, the game stops being fun.

For some reason, the mouse buttons cannot be rebound. The game feels strange to me, since I'm used to E" to interact

reviewText:
TL;DRFor all fans of classic roguelikes, such as ADOM or Nethack, this is a must have! This game captures the feel of these games and mixes it with 3D graphics and first person action in an atmospheric dungeon.


ReviewBarony is a dungeon crawler which is heavily inspired by oldschool RPGs, such as Rogue or Hack. A lot of mechanics, items and interactions are translated from the ASCII based world of classic turn based Roguelikes into a blocky 3D real time environment à la Delver. While the esthetics and first impression reminds a lot of Delver, this dungeon goes a lot deeper in many different ways.

The first person controls feel tight and responsive. Nothing is too complicated and after a few rounds I learned how everything works just fine. But even with the good controls, some things feel clunky. The combat in particular feels unfair at times. You can tell that the developers tried to capture every bit of classic roguelike and put it into 3D, but when it comes to combat, this gets rather complicated. The enemies are just as powerful as in for example Nethack, but in Barony you miss out on the 'luxury' of turn based combat. When you encounter an enemy in Nethack, you can think about the situation, look at your equipment and prepare your next step. In Barony it's do or die! Some classes can die in just a few hits from the very first enemies, which is sure to be a major turn off for a lot of players. In ordinary roguelikes the combat often isn't the main focus, but in a real time 3D dungeon crawler, at least to me, it is.

There aren't that much different items to discover, but the RNG gives the available ones a lot of variety. Every item can be cursed, blessed or have a special power. Food can be rotten or fresh and equipment broken or brand new. It's always a little thrill to identify a new found item.

Speaking of identification: to identify an item you can go the nowadays established way and use a scroll/spell of identification or in Barony you have the option to appraise an item. To appraise an item you have to right click it and hold the mouse button. Then hover over the now visible appraise button and let go. Depending on the characters appraise skill, the length and success rate of the identification differs. For example a merchant can appraise nearly every item very quick, right from the start. A warrior on the other hand appraises really slow and often fails. The appraise mechanic almost feels like the balancing for the unforgiving combat, so you don't always have to rely solely on your luck when it comes to loot.

The dungeon of Barony is great. Even with the 'Minecrafty' esthetic of the game, the environment feels dark, mysterious and dangerous! Every floor is randomly generated and is filled with monsters, items, special locations and traps. You can find a variety of things, from your generic treasure chest to giant falling boulders and succubus summoning fountains. Every part of the dungeon has it's own theme. After about 5 levels the scenery changes and also the general layout of the floors. The first floors look like an abandoned mine, but sooner or later you find yourself inside a dark forest or an ancient labyrinth. Additionally there are secret areas to find, which are tricky to find/survive, but can hold great rewards and that should make every adventurer happy :)

Last but not least, a probably very important aspect for a lot of interested players: the multiplayer. Currently the only inbuilt way to play co-op is in a local network, but appearently the developers are already working on online multiplayer and a lot of other features. There is a way to play online, which is via Hamachi. There are guides on the Barony Community Hub on how to set everything up for online play. I tried it with a friend of mine and in my opinion the multiplayer fits great into the overall experience. It doesn't ruin the atmosphere and even with two players, the game is still really challenging. At some points it may even be more difficult, because you have to split up loot, but that always  depends on how much you can find anyway. Some things are a little bothersome, such as no fast restart option when the whole party dies and no server browser, but if you have ever played some older multiplayer games, you know what's coming. We played for about 3 hours and really had a great time.

ConclusionBarony is by no means a perfect game, but even with it's flaws, especially in combat, it still got me hooked! Where the mechanics can't deliver, the sense of adventure, the atmosphere and the constant drive to delve deeper into the forgotten mines does. Every run teaches you something else, shows you a new creature or an mysterious item. And with a little practice and the right bit of luck, you will advance even further into the depths of Barony with every try you take. Should you feel like this is too much to handle on your own, you can always bring a friend or two. Of course it can and will be frustrating, but there is a lot to find in Barony and if you are a friend of classic roguelikes and would like to experience them from another perspective, this is the game for you.

PROsChallenging gameplay
Randomly generated levels
Great atmosphere
Captures the feeling of a classic roguelike
Co-op multiplayer (only LAN)
CONsReally hard to get into
Combat sometimes feels unfair
Not a lot of item variety
Minecrafty" esthetic
No experience sharing in multiplayer"

reviewText:
TL;DRFor all fans of classic roguelikes, such as ADOM or Nethack, this is a must have! This game captures the feel of these games and mixes it with 3D graphics and first person action in an atmospheric dungeon.


ReviewBarony is a dungeon crawler which is heavily inspired by oldschool RPGs, such as Rogue or Hack. A lot of mechanics, items and interactions are translated from the ASCII based world of classic turn based Roguelikes into a blocky 3D real time environment à la Delver. While the esthetics and first impression reminds a lot of Delver, this dungeon goes a lot deeper in many different ways.

The first person controls feel tight and responsive. Nothing is too complicated and after a few rounds I learned how everything works just fine. But even with the good controls, some things feel clunky. The combat in particular feels unfair at times. You can tell that the developers tried to capture every bit of classic roguelike and put it into 3D, but when it comes to combat, this gets rather complicated. The enemies are just as powerful as in for example Nethack, but in Barony you miss out on the 'luxury' of turn based combat. When you encounter an enemy in Nethack, you can think about the situation, look at your equipment and prepare your next step. In Barony it's do or die! Some classes can die in just a few hits from the very first enemies, which is sure to be a major turn off for a lot of players. In ordinary roguelikes the combat often isn't the main focus, but in a real time 3D dungeon crawler, at least to me, it is.

There aren't that much different items to discover, but the RNG gives the available ones a lot of variety. Every item can be cursed, blessed or have a special power. Food can be rotten or fresh and equipment broken or brand new. It's always a little thrill to identify a new found item.

Speaking of identification: to identify an item you can go the nowadays established way and use a scroll/spell of identification or in Barony you have the option to appraise an item. To appraise an item you have to right click it and hold the mouse button. Then hover over the now visible appraise button and let go. Depending on the characters appraise skill, the length and success rate of the identification differs. For example a merchant can appraise nearly every item very quick, right from the start. A warrior on the other hand appraises really slow and often fails. The appraise mechanic almost feels like the balancing for the unforgiving combat, so you don't always have to rely solely on your luck when it comes to loot.

The dungeon of Barony is great. Even with the 'Minecrafty' esthetic of the game, the environment feels dark, mysterious and dangerous! Every floor is randomly generated and is filled with monsters, items, special locations and traps. You can find a variety of things, from your generic treasure chest to giant falling boulders and succubus summoning fountains. Every part of the dungeon has it's own theme. After about 5 levels the scenery changes and also the general layout of the floors. The first floors look like an abandoned mine, but sooner or later you find yourself inside a dark forest or an ancient labyrinth. Additionally there are secret areas to find, which are tricky to find/survive, but can hold great rewards and that should make every adventurer happy :)

Last but not least, a probably very important aspect for a lot of interested players: the multiplayer. Currently the only inbuilt way to play co-op is in a local network, but appearently the developers are already working on online multiplayer and a lot of other features. There is a way to play online, which is via Hamachi. There are guides on the Barony Community Hub on how to set everything up for online play. I tried it with a friend of mine and in my opinion the multiplayer fits great into the overall experience. It doesn't ruin the atmosphere and even with two players, the game is still really challenging. At some points it may even be more difficult, because you have to split up loot, but that always  depends on how much you can find anyway. Some things are a little bothersome, such as no fast restart option when the whole party dies and no server browser, but if you have ever played some older multiplayer games, you know what's coming. We played for about 3 hours and really had a great time.

ConclusionBarony is by no means a perfect game, but even with it's flaws, especially in combat, it still got me hooked! Where the mechanics can't deliver, the sense of adventure, the atmosphere and the constant drive to delve deeper into the forgotten mines does. Every run teaches you something else, shows you a new creature or an mysterious item. And with a little practice and the right bit of luck, you will advance even further into the depths of Barony with every try you take. Should you feel like this is too much to handle on your own, you can always bring a friend or two. Of course it can and will be frustrating, but there is a lot to find in Barony and if you are a friend of classic roguelikes and would like to experience them from another perspective, this is the game for you.

PROsChallenging gameplay
Randomly generated levels
Great atmosphere
Captures the feeling of a classic roguelike
Co-op multiplayer (only LAN)
CONsReally hard to get into
Combat sometimes feels unfair
Not a lot of item variety
Minecrafty" esthetic
No experience sharing in multiplayer"

reviewText:
Pretty fun little game, if you like dying repeatedly and making no progress. If not, here's my advice:

1) Disable the minotaur that has the ability to teleport to your location every few minutes but for some reason doesn't just kill you outright in the beginning
2) Disable hunger, which pops up more often than a diabetic's
3) Use ranged weapons whenever possible because the melee system is about as refined as Minecraft's

Also, ignore the comparisons drawn in the description. While it has a few features of Nethack (procedurally generated levels and permanent death) it is not a roguelike. While it is a dungeon crawler like Ultima Underworld, the combat isn't even that sophisticated, not to mention the utter lack of content or side stories in comparison. System Shock is also more sophisticated in terms of combat and mobility and the game has essentially nothing in common with Daggerfall other than having repetitive dungeons and character sheets.

What you are getting, for better or worse, is a first-person, real-time Nethack with co-op, that is hard in even less believable ways than Nethack. Without turning the minotaur off, just imagine playing Nethack with a Nethack minotaur that appears based on a timer instead of turns, regardless of level, and who can walk through walls. Without turning the hunger off, imagine getting hungry at about the same rate as you do in Nethack but in real time. Who gets hungry 5 minutes after eating a fist of ham? Do you?

Regardless, the game is successful in other ways. You will improve as a player with every playthrough, just like Nethack, and unlike Nethack it has multiplayer which I suspect was the point of the whole thing in the first place. The game has also been rather stable on all my Windows computers, though I can't speak for other operating systems. At its low price it's hard not to recommend.
